Trump, Inc. How Taxpayers Covered a $1,000 Liquor Bill for Trump Staffers (and More) at Trumpâs Club A top-shelf, closed-door drinking session. $546-a-night hotel rooms. A special government credit card for Mar-a-Lago. Taxpayers foot the costs â and the president profits. by Derek Kravitz for ProPublica May 1, 4 a.m. EDT President Donald Trump, center, with Chinese President Xi Jinping at dinner, during Jinpingâs visit to Mar-a-Lago in April 2017. (Jim Watson/AFP/Getty Images) The Trump Administration The 45th President and His Administration Trump, Inc. Exploring the Mysteries of the Presidentâs Businesses Find âTrump, Inc.â wherever you get your podcasts. This weekâs episode examines the intersection of money, presidential access and security, and the push and pull between government spending and private profits at Mar-a-Lago. In April 2017, Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Mar-a-Lago, President Donald Trumpâs Palm Beach, Florida, estate and club, for a two-day summit. While Xi and his delegation stayed at a nearby hotel, Trump and his advisers stayed at the peach-colored, waterfront resort. That evening, Trump and a dozen of his closest advisers hosted Xi and the Chinese delegation in an ornate dining room where they ate Dover sole and New York strip steak. Those sorts of lavish, formal gatherings are expected for a major bilateral summit. But then there are less formal events. At some point later that evening, a group repaired to Mar-a-Lagoâs Library Bar, a wood-paneled study with a portrait of Trump in tennis whites (titled âThe Visionaryâ) hanging nearby. The group asked the bartender to leave the room so it âcould speak confidentially,â according to an email written by Mar-a-Lagoâs catering director, Brooke Watson. Mar-a-Lago's Catering Director Describes White House Happy Hour for State Department (p. 33) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The Secret Service guarded the door, according to the email. The bartender wasnât allowed to return. And members of the group began pouring themselves drinks. No one paid. Six days later, on April 13, Mar-a-Lago created a bill for those drinks, tallying $838 worth of alcohol plus a 20% service charge. It covered 54 drinks (making for an average price of $18.62 each) of premium liquor: Chopin vodka, Patron and Don Julio Blanco tequilas and Woodford Reserve bourbon. Watsonâs email did not specify how many people consumed the alcohol or who the participants were. (It stated that she was told the participants included then-strategist Steve Bannon and then-deputy chief of staff Joe Hagin. Bannon, who has said he stopped drinking years ago, said he didnât drink at Mar-a-Lago and didnât recall the episode. Hagin did not respond to requests for comment.) Mar-a-Lago's Bill for $1,005.60 for Alcohol Consumed by White House Aides (p. 277) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The bill was sent to the State Department, which objected to covering it. It was then forwarded to the White House, which paid the tab. The unusual cocktail hour underscores a unique push and pull in the current administration: Donald Trumpâs White House pays a bill and Donald Trumpâs club reaps the revenue. (Itâs unclear if the White House asked any of those drinking to reimburse the government; the White House declined to comment.) The premium liquor costs are only the beginning of government spending at Mar-a-Lago that emerges in hundreds of pages of receipts and email correspondence between Trump Organization employees and staffers for the State Department, which oversees presidential diplomatic travel and works with the Secret Service and White House. The emails show that the presidentâs company refused to agree to what was essentially a bulk-purchase agreement with the federal government, and that it charged the maximum allowable federal rate for hotel rooms. The Trump Organization could be obstinate when it came to rates for, say, function rooms at Mar-a-Lago, a problem that was eased when the president signed a law lifting the maximum âmicro-purchaseâ the government can make. Get More Trump, Inc. Stay up to date with email updates from WNYC and ProPublica about their ongoing investigations. The emails have been released as part of an ongoing lawsuit between the nonprofit Property of the People, a Washington-based transparency group, and the federal government. Property of the People provided the emails and receipts to ProPublica and we, in turn, have added them to our tracker of government spending at Trump-owned properties for our interactive graphic Paying the President. (The State Department is expected to release an additional 1,800 pages of records as part of the lawsuit, which was filed under the Freedom of Information Act.) In response to questions from ProPublica, the State Department asked for and received the documents described in this article. State Department officials promised a detailed response, but then declined comment. The documents reveal the intersection between Trumpâs conflicting interests. The emails show that âMar-a-Lago wanted to have the government money without the government rules,â said Charles Tiefer, a law professor at the University of Baltimore who served on the congressionally chartered Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan. Listen to the Episode A few months after Trumpâs inauguration, the State Department proposed a contract that would pay $200,000 for all room costs for federal employees who stay at Mar-a-Lago over the first term of his presidency. But Mar-a-Lago rejected the governmentâs proposal. Instead, Trumpâs resort bills the government the maximum permitted by federal rules: 300% of the governmentâs per diem rate, which works out to $546 per night. Mar-a-Lago rejected the proposed flat-fee arrangement, according to the emails, because of concerns the clubâs lawyers had about the Federal Acquisition Regulation, or FAR, which governs federal purchases and is overseen by contracting officers. FAR seeks to promote competition and maintain âthe publicâs trust.â The emails suggest the Trump Organization was worried that the lack of competitive bidding could run afoul of federal rules, among other concerns. A State Department staffer wrote in May 2017 that Mar-a-Lagoâs attorneys brought up federal âsmall business set-asideâ requirements, which set strict rules for sole-source government bids for small businesses. The State Department staffer wrote that Mar-a-Lagoâs âconcerns are based on their general lack of knowledge on the applicability of the FAR regulations.â A State Department Travel Card is Created Just for Mar-a-Lago (p. 16) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago and the Trump Organization did not respond to ProPublicaâs requests for comment. Since Mar-a-Lago wouldnât agree to a bulk contract, the State Department had to go to Plan B. When it came to the meeting with Chinaâs president, for example, the agency had to go into some contortions to make Mar-a-Lagoâs $546 nightly room rate square with its rules on competitive bidding, given that there are other less expensive hotels nearby. At least 16 staffers stayed at the Hampton Inn in West Palm Beach; at least eight stayed at the nearby Hilton Garden Inn; and four others stayed at the Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa, where the press pool also stayed, according to a hotel manifest obtained through the FOIA lawsuit. The government-negotiated rates at those establishments ranged from $195 to $305 per night. The State Department Negotiated a Much Cheaper Rate for a Nearby Hotel for the April 2017 Trip (p. 128) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note (At least 24 White House and federal staffers stayed at Mar-a-Lago during the Xi visit. They included then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson; then-chief of staff Reince Priebus; then-Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; then-National Economic Council adviser Gary Cohn; and other advisers, past and present, such as Bannon, Hope Hicks, Stephen Miller and Sean Spicer.) A Manifest of Where Federal Employees Stayed During the April 2017 Mar-a-Lago Trip (p. 126) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The State Department also broke with protocol regarding taxpayer-funded travel and applied for a Citibank travel card just for Mar-a-Lago visits. Meanwhile, other problems emerged: Mar-a-Lago canât process charges over $10,000, which led to problems when the club split bills and charged the government card for multiple transactions, emails show. Mar-a-Lago Can Only Charge Up to $10,000 On its Systems, Says State Department (p. 76) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago refused government requests to waive the costs of its âfunction roomâ for press and other official meetings in April 2017, leading to a near-violation of a $3,500 government spending cap. Last year, Trump signed a law that lifted that cap, known as the âmicro-purchase threshold,â from $3,500 to $10,000. The law does not appear to have been aimed at facilitating spending at Mar-a-Lago, but it allows the club to avoid additional government contracting rules when charging sums below $10,000.In one instance, after the government was charged more than $3,500 for conference space at Mar-a-Lago, it asked the Trump Organization for a 10% discount so that it wouldnât violate the micro-purchase threshold. Mar-a-Lago relented, but only after months of haggling. The State Department Asks Mar-a-Lago for a 10% Discount on a Meeting Room, to Comply with Federal Rules (p. 45) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note In the emails, the director of presidential travel support, Michael Dobbs, frequently described the creation of a charge card unique to Mar-a-Lago as a âheadache.â State Department Contracting Officer Says Mar-a-Lago is a 'Headache' (p. 430) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note As Steve Schooner, a professor of government contracting law at George Washington University, put it, âThe fact that we have a State Department contracting officer saying this is a headache is a reminder that, but for the relationship with President Trump, this would not be a contract the government would be having. Thatâs a problem.â Many of the expenses incurred by White House staff are arranged and paid for by the White Houseâs Office of Administration. These expenses are not required to be made public. The same goes for Secret Service spending to protect the president on such visits. (The Government Accountability Office released a report last month evaluating spending at Mar-a-Lago in February and March 2017 and found that a total of $60,000 was spent at the hotel during four trips; the figure ran to $13.6 million when costs for plane travel, secret service, security and other logistics were included.) The State Department payments, and its work on behalf of the White House and other traveling staff, are considered public records. Read More Paying the President Track the money that goes into the presidentâs pocket from political campaigns and taxpayers. Between 2015 and June of 2018, at least $16.1 million has poured into Trump Organization-managed and branded hotels, golf courses and restaurants from his campaign, Republican organizations and government agencies. Because Trumpâs business empire is overseen by a trust of which he is the sole beneficiary, he profits from these hotel stays, banquet hall rentals and meals. Federal spending rules donât specifically address agency-level spending on alcohol that is directly invoiced to the government, as occurred with the $1,000 bar tab at Mar-a-Lago. The State Department and the White House have had exemptions included in their appropriations legislation to allow for alcohol purchases. Individual government employees are not permitted to use charge cards for âimproperâ purposes, such as alcohol, and federal per diem rules allow for charges for breakfast, lunch, dinner and related tips and taxes but specifically exclude alcoholic drinks. Six government contracting experts said Mar-a-Lago may be violating rules requiring competitive bids. They argue that Mar-a-Lagoâs practice of invoicing meeting spaces, hotel stays and meals separately is a way to get around federal spending rules. âMar-a-Lago didnât want to compete, they wanted to sneak around the requirements, and charge much higher prices than the competition,â said Tiefer, who served as deputy general counsel with the House of Representatives for 11 years. âItâs not the first time in history that vendors have tried to get around the rules by charging individual components. This is familiar to every contracting officer. And itâs wrong. Itâs not just a technicality. Itâs not a game. The only safeguard the public has against the Trumps swallowing up all the government business is at least minimal competition.â Several experts contend the State Department is exploiting loopholes in government spending rules to facilitate official gatherings at Mar-a-Lago. âItâs one of the biggest fears coming true, that they are bending over backwards to help the Trump Organization,â said Scott Amey, general counsel of the Project On Government Oversight. âIâm frustrated the State Department would exploit the system to bill Uncle Sam and the taxpayers. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. Itâs a worst-case scenario when it comes to conflicts of interest, with the president and his children putting themselves and profits ahead of the public.â âTrump, Inc.â is exploring whether the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still enforcing consumer financial laws and holding companies accountable. We want to hear from people who work at the agency or left recently (particularly those familiar with enforcement actions, supervisory exams and areas such as payday lending and debt collection). Weâre also hoping to hear from consumers and companies who have interacted with the bureau in recent years. Find out more and tell us what you know. âTrump, Inc.â is a production of WNYC Studios and ProPublica. Support our work by visiting donate.propublica.org or by becoming a supporting member of WNYC. Subscribe here or wherever you get your podcasts. Filed under: The Trump Administration Get the latest news from ProPublica every afternoon. Derek Kravitz Derek Kravitz was the research editor at ProPublica and covered the Trump administration. But an investigation of a dozen Trump deals shows deep family involvement in projects that often involved deceptive practices.Trump and Taxes: The Art of the Dodge â âTrump, Inc.â Podcast Donald Trump has multiple different ways of playing the game when it comes to taxes â and he always seems to come out the winner.Trumpâs Tangled Relationship With Saudi Arabia â âTrump, Inc.â Podcast Extra In the wake of the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, we discuss President Donald Trumpâs business interests in the kingdom. html.textContent: Trump, Inc. How Taxpayers Covered a $1,000 Liquor Bill for Trump Staffers (and More) at Trumpâs Club A top-shelf, closed-door drinking session. $546-a-night hotel rooms. A special government credit card for Mar-a-Lago. Taxpayers foot the costs â and the president profits. by Derek Kravitz for ProPublica May 1, 4 a.m. EDT President Donald Trump, center, with Chinese President Xi Jinping at dinner, during Jinpingâs visit to Mar-a-Lago in April 2017. (Jim Watson/AFP/Getty Images) The Trump Administration The 45th President and His Administration Trump, Inc. Exploring the Mysteries of the Presidentâs Businesses Find âTrump, Inc.â wherever you get your podcasts. This weekâs episode examines the intersection of money, presidential access and security, and the push and pull between government spending and private profits at Mar-a-Lago. In April 2017, Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Mar-a-Lago, President Donald Trumpâs Palm Beach, Florida, estate and club, for a two-day summit. While Xi and his delegation stayed at a nearby hotel, Trump and his advisers stayed at the peach-colored, waterfront resort. That evening, Trump and a dozen of his closest advisers hosted Xi and the Chinese delegation in an ornate dining room where they ate Dover sole and New York strip steak. Those sorts of lavish, formal gatherings are expected for a major bilateral summit. But then there are less formal events. At some point later that evening, a group repaired to Mar-a-Lagoâs Library Bar, a wood-paneled study with a portrait of Trump in tennis whites (titled âThe Visionaryâ) hanging nearby. The group asked the bartender to leave the room so it âcould speak confidentially,â according to an email written by Mar-a-Lagoâs catering director, Brooke Watson. Mar-a-Lago's Catering Director Describes White House Happy Hour for State Department (p. 33) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The Secret Service guarded the door, according to the email. The bartender wasnât allowed to return. And members of the group began pouring themselves drinks. No one paid. Six days later, on April 13, Mar-a-Lago created a bill for those drinks, tallying $838 worth of alcohol plus a 20% service charge. It covered 54 drinks (making for an average price of $18.62 each) of premium liquor: Chopin vodka, Patron and Don Julio Blanco tequilas and Woodford Reserve bourbon. Watsonâs email did not specify how many people consumed the alcohol or who the participants were. (It stated that she was told the participants included then-strategist Steve Bannon and then-deputy chief of staff Joe Hagin. Bannon, who has said he stopped drinking years ago, said he didnât drink at Mar-a-Lago and didnât recall the episode. Hagin did not respond to requests for comment.) Mar-a-Lago's Bill for $1,005.60 for Alcohol Consumed by White House Aides (p. 277) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The bill was sent to the State Department, which objected to covering it. It was then forwarded to the White House, which paid the tab. The unusual cocktail hour underscores a unique push and pull in the current administration: Donald Trumpâs White House pays a bill and Donald Trumpâs club reaps the revenue. (Itâs unclear if the White House asked any of those drinking to reimburse the government; the White House declined to comment.) The premium liquor costs are only the beginning of government spending at Mar-a-Lago that emerges in hundreds of pages of receipts and email correspondence between Trump Organization employees and staffers for the State Department, which oversees presidential diplomatic travel and works with the Secret Service and White House. The emails show that the presidentâs company refused to agree to what was essentially a bulk-purchase agreement with the federal government, and that it charged the maximum allowable federal rate for hotel rooms. The Trump Organization could be obstinate when it came to rates for, say, function rooms at Mar-a-Lago, a problem that was eased when the president signed a law lifting the maximum âmicro-purchaseâ the government can make. Get More Trump, Inc. Stay up to date with email updates from WNYC and ProPublica about their ongoing investigations. The emails have been released as part of an ongoing lawsuit between the nonprofit Property of the People, a Washington-based transparency group, and the federal government. Property of the People provided the emails and receipts to ProPublica and we, in turn, have added them to our tracker of government spending at Trump-owned properties for our interactive graphic Paying the President. (The State Department is expected to release an additional 1,800 pages of records as part of the lawsuit, which was filed under the Freedom of Information Act.) In response to questions from ProPublica, the State Department asked for and received the documents described in this article. State Department officials promised a detailed response, but then declined comment. The documents reveal the intersection between Trumpâs conflicting interests. The emails show that âMar-a-Lago wanted to have the government money without the government rules,â said Charles Tiefer, a law professor at the University of Baltimore who served on the congressionally chartered Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan. Listen to the Episode A few months after Trumpâs inauguration, the State Department proposed a contract that would pay $200,000 for all room costs for federal employees who stay at Mar-a-Lago over the first term of his presidency. But Mar-a-Lago rejected the governmentâs proposal. Instead, Trumpâs resort bills the government the maximum permitted by federal rules: 300% of the governmentâs per diem rate, which works out to $546 per night. Mar-a-Lago rejected the proposed flat-fee arrangement, according to the emails, because of concerns the clubâs lawyers had about the Federal Acquisition Regulation, or FAR, which governs federal purchases and is overseen by contracting officers. FAR seeks to promote competition and maintain âthe publicâs trust.â The emails suggest the Trump Organization was worried that the lack of competitive bidding could run afoul of federal rules, among other concerns. A State Department staffer wrote in May 2017 that Mar-a-Lagoâs attorneys brought up federal âsmall business set-asideâ requirements, which set strict rules for sole-source government bids for small businesses. The State Department staffer wrote that Mar-a-Lagoâs âconcerns are based on their general lack of knowledge on the applicability of the FAR regulations.â A State Department Travel Card is Created Just for Mar-a-Lago (p. 16) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago and the Trump Organization did not respond to ProPublicaâs requests for comment. Since Mar-a-Lago wouldnât agree to a bulk contract, the State Department had to go to Plan B. When it came to the meeting with Chinaâs president, for example, the agency had to go into some contortions to make Mar-a-Lagoâs $546 nightly room rate square with its rules on competitive bidding, given that there are other less expensive hotels nearby. At least 16 staffers stayed at the Hampton Inn in West Palm Beach; at least eight stayed at the nearby Hilton Garden Inn; and four others stayed at the Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa, where the press pool also stayed, according to a hotel manifest obtained through the FOIA lawsuit. The government-negotiated rates at those establishments ranged from $195 to $305 per night. The State Department Negotiated a Much Cheaper Rate for a Nearby Hotel for the April 2017 Trip (p. 128) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note (At least 24 White House and federal staffers stayed at Mar-a-Lago during the Xi visit. They included then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson; then-chief of staff Reince Priebus; then-Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; then-National Economic Council adviser Gary Cohn; and other advisers, past and present, such as Bannon, Hope Hicks, Stephen Miller and Sean Spicer.) A Manifest of Where Federal Employees Stayed During the April 2017 Mar-a-Lago Trip (p. 126) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The State Department also broke with protocol regarding taxpayer-funded travel and applied for a Citibank travel card just for Mar-a-Lago visits. Meanwhile, other problems emerged: Mar-a-Lago canât process charges over $10,000, which led to problems when the club split bills and charged the government card for multiple transactions, emails show. Mar-a-Lago Can Only Charge Up to $10,000 On its Systems, Says State Department (p. 76) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago refused government requests to waive the costs of its âfunction roomâ for press and other official meetings in April 2017, leading to a near-violation of a $3,500 government spending cap. Last year, Trump signed a law that lifted that cap, known as the âmicro-purchase threshold,â from $3,500 to $10,000. The law does not appear to have been aimed at facilitating spending at Mar-a-Lago, but it allows the club to avoid additional government contracting rules when charging sums below $10,000.In one instance, after the government was charged more than $3,500 for conference space at Mar-a-Lago, it asked the Trump Organization for a 10% discount so that it wouldnât violate the micro-purchase threshold. Mar-a-Lago relented, but only after months of haggling. The State Department Asks Mar-a-Lago for a 10% Discount on a Meeting Room, to Comply with Federal Rules (p. 45) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note In the emails, the director of presidential travel support, Michael Dobbs, frequently described the creation of a charge card unique to Mar-a-Lago as a âheadache.â State Department Contracting Officer Says Mar-a-Lago is a 'Headache' (p. 430) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note As Steve Schooner, a professor of government contracting law at George Washington University, put it, âThe fact that we have a State Department contracting officer saying this is a headache is a reminder that, but for the relationship with President Trump, this would not be a contract the government would be having. Thatâs a problem.â Many of the expenses incurred by White House staff are arranged and paid for by the White Houseâs Office of Administration. These expenses are not required to be made public. The same goes for Secret Service spending to protect the president on such visits. (The Government Accountability Office released a report last month evaluating spending at Mar-a-Lago in February and March 2017 and found that a total of $60,000 was spent at the hotel during four trips; the figure ran to $13.6 million when costs for plane travel, secret service, security and other logistics were included.) The State Department payments, and its work on behalf of the White House and other traveling staff, are considered public records. Read More Paying the President Track the money that goes into the presidentâs pocket from political campaigns and taxpayers. Between 2015 and June of 2018, at least $16.1 million has poured into Trump Organization-managed and branded hotels, golf courses and restaurants from his campaign, Republican organizations and government agencies. Because Trumpâs business empire is overseen by a trust of which he is the sole beneficiary, he profits from these hotel stays, banquet hall rentals and meals. Federal spending rules donât specifically address agency-level spending on alcohol that is directly invoiced to the government, as occurred with the $1,000 bar tab at Mar-a-Lago. The State Department and the White House have had exemptions included in their appropriations legislation to allow for alcohol purchases. Individual government employees are not permitted to use charge cards for âimproperâ purposes, such as alcohol, and federal per diem rules allow for charges for breakfast, lunch, dinner and related tips and taxes but specifically exclude alcoholic drinks. Six government contracting experts said Mar-a-Lago may be violating rules requiring competitive bids. They argue that Mar-a-Lagoâs practice of invoicing meeting spaces, hotel stays and meals separately is a way to get around federal spending rules. âMar-a-Lago didnât want to compete, they wanted to sneak around the requirements, and charge much higher prices than the competition,â said Tiefer, who served as deputy general counsel with the House of Representatives for 11 years. âItâs not the first time in history that vendors have tried to get around the rules by charging individual components. This is familiar to every contracting officer. And itâs wrong. Itâs not just a technicality. Itâs not a game. The only safeguard the public has against the Trumps swallowing up all the government business is at least minimal competition.â Several experts contend the State Department is exploiting loopholes in government spending rules to facilitate official gatherings at Mar-a-Lago. âItâs one of the biggest fears coming true, that they are bending over backwards to help the Trump Organization,â said Scott Amey, general counsel of the Project On Government Oversight. âIâm frustrated the State Department would exploit the system to bill Uncle Sam and the taxpayers. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. Itâs a worst-case scenario when it comes to conflicts of interest, with the president and his children putting themselves and profits ahead of the public.â âTrump, Inc.â is exploring whether the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still enforcing consumer financial laws and holding companies accountable. We want to hear from people who work at the agency or left recently (particularly those familiar with enforcement actions, supervisory exams and areas such as payday lending and debt collection). Weâre also hoping to hear from consumers and companies who have interacted with the bureau in recent years. Find out more and tell us what you know. âTrump, Inc.â is a production of WNYC Studios and ProPublica. Support our work by visiting donate.propublica.org or by becoming a supporting member of WNYC. Subscribe here or wherever you get your podcasts. At some point later that evening, a group repaired to Mar-a-Lagoâs Library Bar, a wood-paneled study with a portrait of Trump in tennis whites (titled âThe Visionaryâ) hanging nearby. The group asked the bartender to leave the room so it âcould speak confidentially,â according to an email written by Mar-a-Lagoâs catering director, Brooke Watson. Mar-a-Lago's Catering Director Describes White House Happy Hour for State Department (p. 33) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The Secret Service guarded the door, according to the email. The bartender wasnât allowed to return. And members of the group began pouring themselves drinks. No one paid. Six days later, on April 13, Mar-a-Lago created a bill for those drinks, tallying $838 worth of alcohol plus a 20% service charge. It covered 54 drinks (making for an average price of $18.62 each) of premium liquor: Chopin vodka, Patron and Don Julio Blanco tequilas and Woodford Reserve bourbon. Watsonâs email did not specify how many people consumed the alcohol or who the participants were. (It stated that she was told the participants included then-strategist Steve Bannon and then-deputy chief of staff Joe Hagin. Bannon, who has said he stopped drinking years ago, said he didnât drink at Mar-a-Lago and didnât recall the episode. Hagin did not respond to requests for comment.) Mar-a-Lago's Bill for $1,005.60 for Alcohol Consumed by White House Aides (p. 277) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The bill was sent to the State Department, which objected to covering it. It was then forwarded to the White House, which paid the tab. The unusual cocktail hour underscores a unique push and pull in the current administration: Donald Trumpâs White House pays a bill and Donald Trumpâs club reaps the revenue. (Itâs unclear if the White House asked any of those drinking to reimburse the government; the White House declined to comment.) The premium liquor costs are only the beginning of government spending at Mar-a-Lago that emerges in hundreds of pages of receipts and email correspondence between Trump Organization employees and staffers for the State Department, which oversees presidential diplomatic travel and works with the Secret Service and White House. The emails show that the presidentâs company refused to agree to what was essentially a bulk-purchase agreement with the federal government, and that it charged the maximum allowable federal rate for hotel rooms. The Trump Organization could be obstinate when it came to rates for, say, function rooms at Mar-a-Lago, a problem that was eased when the president signed a law lifting the maximum âmicro-purchaseâ the government can make. Get More Trump, Inc. Stay up to date with email updates from WNYC and ProPublica about their ongoing investigations. The emails have been released as part of an ongoing lawsuit between the nonprofit Property of the People, a Washington-based transparency group, and the federal government. Property of the People provided the emails and receipts to ProPublica and we, in turn, have added them to our tracker of government spending at Trump-owned properties for our interactive graphic Paying the President. (The State Department is expected to release an additional 1,800 pages of records as part of the lawsuit, which was filed under the Freedom of Information Act.) In response to questions from ProPublica, the State Department asked for and received the documents described in this article. State Department officials promised a detailed response, but then declined comment. The documents reveal the intersection between Trumpâs conflicting interests. The emails show that âMar-a-Lago wanted to have the government money without the government rules,â said Charles Tiefer, a law professor at the University of Baltimore who served on the congressionally chartered Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan. Listen to the Episode A few months after Trumpâs inauguration, the State Department proposed a contract that would pay $200,000 for all room costs for federal employees who stay at Mar-a-Lago over the first term of his presidency. But Mar-a-Lago rejected the governmentâs proposal. Instead, Trumpâs resort bills the government the maximum permitted by federal rules: 300% of the governmentâs per diem rate, which works out to $546 per night. Mar-a-Lago rejected the proposed flat-fee arrangement, according to the emails, because of concerns the clubâs lawyers had about the Federal Acquisition Regulation, or FAR, which governs federal purchases and is overseen by contracting officers. FAR seeks to promote competition and maintain âthe publicâs trust.â The emails suggest the Trump Organization was worried that the lack of competitive bidding could run afoul of federal rules, among other concerns. A State Department staffer wrote in May 2017 that Mar-a-Lagoâs attorneys brought up federal âsmall business set-asideâ requirements, which set strict rules for sole-source government bids for small businesses. The State Department staffer wrote that Mar-a-Lagoâs âconcerns are based on their general lack of knowledge on the applicability of the FAR regulations.â A State Department Travel Card is Created Just for Mar-a-Lago (p. 16) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago and the Trump Organization did not respond to ProPublicaâs requests for comment. Since Mar-a-Lago wouldnât agree to a bulk contract, the State Department had to go to Plan B. When it came to the meeting with Chinaâs president, for example, the agency had to go into some contortions to make Mar-a-Lagoâs $546 nightly room rate square with its rules on competitive bidding, given that there are other less expensive hotels nearby. At least 16 staffers stayed at the Hampton Inn in West Palm Beach; at least eight stayed at the nearby Hilton Garden Inn; and four others stayed at the Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa, where the press pool also stayed, according to a hotel manifest obtained through the FOIA lawsuit. The government-negotiated rates at those establishments ranged from $195 to $305 per night. The State Department Negotiated a Much Cheaper Rate for a Nearby Hotel for the April 2017 Trip (p. 128) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note (At least 24 White House and federal staffers stayed at Mar-a-Lago during the Xi visit. They included then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson; then-chief of staff Reince Priebus; then-Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; then-National Economic Council adviser Gary Cohn; and other advisers, past and present, such as Bannon, Hope Hicks, Stephen Miller and Sean Spicer.) A Manifest of Where Federal Employees Stayed During the April 2017 Mar-a-Lago Trip (p. 126) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The State Department also broke with protocol regarding taxpayer-funded travel and applied for a Citibank travel card just for Mar-a-Lago visits. Meanwhile, other problems emerged: Mar-a-Lago canât process charges over $10,000, which led to problems when the club split bills and charged the government card for multiple transactions, emails show. Mar-a-Lago Can Only Charge Up to $10,000 On its Systems, Says State Department (p. 76) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago refused government requests to waive the costs of its âfunction roomâ for press and other official meetings in April 2017, leading to a near-violation of a $3,500 government spending cap. Last year, Trump signed a law that lifted that cap, known as the âmicro-purchase threshold,â from $3,500 to $10,000. The law does not appear to have been aimed at facilitating spending at Mar-a-Lago, but it allows the club to avoid additional government contracting rules when charging sums below $10,000.In one instance, after the government was charged more than $3,500 for conference space at Mar-a-Lago, it asked the Trump Organization for a 10% discount so that it wouldnât violate the micro-purchase threshold. Mar-a-Lago relented, but only after months of haggling. The State Department Asks Mar-a-Lago for a 10% Discount on a Meeting Room, to Comply with Federal Rules (p. 45) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note In the emails, the director of presidential travel support, Michael Dobbs, frequently described the creation of a charge card unique to Mar-a-Lago as a âheadache.â State Department Contracting Officer Says Mar-a-Lago is a 'Headache' (p. 430) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note As Steve Schooner, a professor of government contracting law at George Washington University, put it, âThe fact that we have a State Department contracting officer saying this is a headache is a reminder that, but for the relationship with President Trump, this would not be a contract the government would be having. Thatâs a problem.â Many of the expenses incurred by White House staff are arranged and paid for by the White Houseâs Office of Administration. These expenses are not required to be made public. The same goes for Secret Service spending to protect the president on such visits. (The Government Accountability Office released a report last month evaluating spending at Mar-a-Lago in February and March 2017 and found that a total of $60,000 was spent at the hotel during four trips; the figure ran to $13.6 million when costs for plane travel, secret service, security and other logistics were included.) The State Department payments, and its work on behalf of the White House and other traveling staff, are considered public records. Read More Paying the President Track the money that goes into the presidentâs pocket from political campaigns and taxpayers. Between 2015 and June of 2018, at least $16.1 million has poured into Trump Organization-managed and branded hotels, golf courses and restaurants from his campaign, Republican organizations and government agencies. Because Trumpâs business empire is overseen by a trust of which he is the sole beneficiary, he profits from these hotel stays, banquet hall rentals and meals. Federal spending rules donât specifically address agency-level spending on alcohol that is directly invoiced to the government, as occurred with the $1,000 bar tab at Mar-a-Lago. The State Department and the White House have had exemptions included in their appropriations legislation to allow for alcohol purchases. Individual government employees are not permitted to use charge cards for âimproperâ purposes, such as alcohol, and federal per diem rules allow for charges for breakfast, lunch, dinner and related tips and taxes but specifically exclude alcoholic drinks. Six government contracting experts said Mar-a-Lago may be violating rules requiring competitive bids. They argue that Mar-a-Lagoâs practice of invoicing meeting spaces, hotel stays and meals separately is a way to get around federal spending rules. âMar-a-Lago didnât want to compete, they wanted to sneak around the requirements, and charge much higher prices than the competition,â said Tiefer, who served as deputy general counsel with the House of Representatives for 11 years. âItâs not the first time in history that vendors have tried to get around the rules by charging individual components. This is familiar to every contracting officer. And itâs wrong. Itâs not just a technicality. Itâs not a game. The only safeguard the public has against the Trumps swallowing up all the government business is at least minimal competition.â Several experts contend the State Department is exploiting loopholes in government spending rules to facilitate official gatherings at Mar-a-Lago. âItâs one of the biggest fears coming true, that they are bending over backwards to help the Trump Organization,â said Scott Amey, general counsel of the Project On Government Oversight. âIâm frustrated the State Department would exploit the system to bill Uncle Sam and the taxpayers. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. Itâs a worst-case scenario when it comes to conflicts of interest, with the president and his children putting themselves and profits ahead of the public.â âTrump, Inc.â is exploring whether the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still enforcing consumer financial laws and holding companies accountable. We want to hear from people who work at the agency or left recently (particularly those familiar with enforcement actions, supervisory exams and areas such as payday lending and debt collection). Weâre also hoping to hear from consumers and companies who have interacted with the bureau in recent years. Find out more and tell us what you know. âTrump, Inc.â is a production of WNYC Studios and ProPublica. Support our work by visiting donate.propublica.org or by becoming a supporting member of WNYC. Subscribe here or wherever you get your podcasts. Thatâs a problem.â Many of the expenses incurred by White House staff are arranged and paid for by the White Houseâs Office of Administration. These expenses are not required to be made public. The same goes for Secret Service spending to protect the president on such visits. (The Government Accountability Office released a report last month evaluating spending at Mar-a-Lago in February and March 2017 and found that a total of $60,000 was spent at the hotel during four trips; the figure ran to $13.6 million when costs for plane travel, secret service, security and other logistics were included.) The State Department payments, and its work on behalf of the White House and other traveling staff, are considered public records. Read More Paying the President Track the money that goes into the presidentâs pocket from political campaigns and taxpayers. Between 2015 and June of 2018, at least $16.1 million has poured into Trump Organization-managed and branded hotels, golf courses and restaurants from his campaign, Republican organizations and government agencies. Because Trumpâs business empire is overseen by a trust of which he is the sole beneficiary, he profits from these hotel stays, banquet hall rentals and meals. Federal spending rules donât specifically address agency-level spending on alcohol that is directly invoiced to the government, as occurred with the $1,000 bar tab at Mar-a-Lago. The State Department and the White House have had exemptions included in their appropriations legislation to allow for alcohol purchases. Individual government employees are not permitted to use charge cards for âimproperâ purposes, such as alcohol, and federal per diem rules allow for charges for breakfast, lunch, dinner and related tips and taxes but specifically exclude alcoholic drinks. Six government contracting experts said Mar-a-Lago may be violating rules requiring competitive bids. They argue that Mar-a-Lagoâs practice of invoicing meeting spaces, hotel stays and meals separately is a way to get around federal spending rules. âMar-a-Lago didnât want to compete, they wanted to sneak around the requirements, and charge much higher prices than the competition,â said Tiefer, who served as deputy general counsel with the House of Representatives for 11 years. âItâs not the first time in history that vendors have tried to get around the rules by charging individual components. This is familiar to every contracting officer. And itâs wrong. Itâs not just a technicality. Itâs not a game. The only safeguard the public has against the Trumps swallowing up all the government business is at least minimal competition.â Several experts contend the State Department is exploiting loopholes in government spending rules to facilitate official gatherings at Mar-a-Lago. âItâs one of the biggest fears coming true, that they are bending over backwards to help the Trump Organization,â said Scott Amey, general counsel of the Project On Government Oversight. âIâm frustrated the State Department would exploit the system to bill Uncle Sam and the taxpayers. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. Itâs a worst-case scenario when it comes to conflicts of interest, with the president and his children putting themselves and profits ahead of the public.â âTrump, Inc.â is exploring whether the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still enforcing consumer financial laws and holding companies accountable. We want to hear from people who work at the agency or left recently (particularly those familiar with enforcement actions, supervisory exams and areas such as payday lending and debt collection). Weâre also hoping to hear from consumers and companies who have interacted with the bureau in recent years. Find out more and tell us what you know. âTrump, Inc.â is a production of WNYC Studios and ProPublica. Support our work by visiting donate.propublica.org or by becoming a supporting member of WNYC. Subscribe here or wherever you get your podcasts. html.textContent: The Trump Administration The 45th President and His Administration Trump, Inc. Exploring the Mysteries of the Presidentâs Businesses Find âTrump, Inc.â wherever you get your podcasts. This weekâs episode examines the intersection of money, presidential access and security, and the push and pull between government spending and private profits at Mar-a-Lago. In April 2017, Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Mar-a-Lago, President Donald Trumpâs Palm Beach, Florida, estate and club, for a two-day summit. While Xi and his delegation stayed at a nearby hotel, Trump and his advisers stayed at the peach-colored, waterfront resort. That evening, Trump and a dozen of his closest advisers hosted Xi and the Chinese delegation in an ornate dining room where they ate Dover sole and New York strip steak. Those sorts of lavish, formal gatherings are expected for a major bilateral summit. But then there are less formal events. At some point later that evening, a group repaired to Mar-a-Lagoâs Library Bar, a wood-paneled study with a portrait of Trump in tennis whites (titled âThe Visionaryâ) hanging nearby. The group asked the bartender to leave the room so it âcould speak confidentially,â according to an email written by Mar-a-Lagoâs catering director, Brooke Watson. Mar-a-Lago's Catering Director Describes White House Happy Hour for State Department (p. 33) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The Secret Service guarded the door, according to the email. The bartender wasnât allowed to return. And members of the group began pouring themselves drinks. No one paid. Six days later, on April 13, Mar-a-Lago created a bill for those drinks, tallying $838 worth of alcohol plus a 20% service charge. It covered 54 drinks (making for an average price of $18.62 each) of premium liquor: Chopin vodka, Patron and Don Julio Blanco tequilas and Woodford Reserve bourbon. Watsonâs email did not specify how many people consumed the alcohol or who the participants were. (It stated that she was told the participants included then-strategist Steve Bannon and then-deputy chief of staff Joe Hagin. Bannon, who has said he stopped drinking years ago, said he didnât drink at Mar-a-Lago and didnât recall the episode. Hagin did not respond to requests for comment.) Mar-a-Lago's Bill for $1,005.60 for Alcohol Consumed by White House Aides (p. 277) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The bill was sent to the State Department, which objected to covering it. It was then forwarded to the White House, which paid the tab. The unusual cocktail hour underscores a unique push and pull in the current administration: Donald Trumpâs White House pays a bill and Donald Trumpâs club reaps the revenue. (Itâs unclear if the White House asked any of those drinking to reimburse the government; the White House declined to comment.) The premium liquor costs are only the beginning of government spending at Mar-a-Lago that emerges in hundreds of pages of receipts and email correspondence between Trump Organization employees and staffers for the State Department, which oversees presidential diplomatic travel and works with the Secret Service and White House. The emails show that the presidentâs company refused to agree to what was essentially a bulk-purchase agreement with the federal government, and that it charged the maximum allowable federal rate for hotel rooms. The Trump Organization could be obstinate when it came to rates for, say, function rooms at Mar-a-Lago, a problem that was eased when the president signed a law lifting the maximum âmicro-purchaseâ the government can make. Get More Trump, Inc. Stay up to date with email updates from WNYC and ProPublica about their ongoing investigations. The emails have been released as part of an ongoing lawsuit between the nonprofit Property of the People, a Washington-based transparency group, and the federal government. Property of the People provided the emails and receipts to ProPublica and we, in turn, have added them to our tracker of government spending at Trump-owned properties for our interactive graphic Paying the President. (The State Department is expected to release an additional 1,800 pages of records as part of the lawsuit, which was filed under the Freedom of Information Act.) In response to questions from ProPublica, the State Department asked for and received the documents described in this article. State Department officials promised a detailed response, but then declined comment. The documents reveal the intersection between Trumpâs conflicting interests. The emails show that âMar-a-Lago wanted to have the government money without the government rules,â said Charles Tiefer, a law professor at the University of Baltimore who served on the congressionally chartered Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan. Listen to the Episode A few months after Trumpâs inauguration, the State Department proposed a contract that would pay $200,000 for all room costs for federal employees who stay at Mar-a-Lago over the first term of his presidency. But Mar-a-Lago rejected the governmentâs proposal. Instead, Trumpâs resort bills the government the maximum permitted by federal rules: 300% of the governmentâs per diem rate, which works out to $546 per night. Mar-a-Lago rejected the proposed flat-fee arrangement, according to the emails, because of concerns the clubâs lawyers had about the Federal Acquisition Regulation, or FAR, which governs federal purchases and is overseen by contracting officers. FAR seeks to promote competition and maintain âthe publicâs trust.â The emails suggest the Trump Organization was worried that the lack of competitive bidding could run afoul of federal rules, among other concerns. A State Department staffer wrote in May 2017 that Mar-a-Lagoâs attorneys brought up federal âsmall business set-asideâ requirements, which set strict rules for sole-source government bids for small businesses. The State Department staffer wrote that Mar-a-Lagoâs âconcerns are based on their general lack of knowledge on the applicability of the FAR regulations.â A State Department Travel Card is Created Just for Mar-a-Lago (p. 16) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago and the Trump Organization did not respond to ProPublicaâs requests for comment. Since Mar-a-Lago wouldnât agree to a bulk contract, the State Department had to go to Plan B. When it came to the meeting with Chinaâs president, for example, the agency had to go into some contortions to make Mar-a-Lagoâs $546 nightly room rate square with its rules on competitive bidding, given that there are other less expensive hotels nearby. At least 16 staffers stayed at the Hampton Inn in West Palm Beach; at least eight stayed at the nearby Hilton Garden Inn; and four others stayed at the Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa, where the press pool also stayed, according to a hotel manifest obtained through the FOIA lawsuit. The government-negotiated rates at those establishments ranged from $195 to $305 per night. The State Department Negotiated a Much Cheaper Rate for a Nearby Hotel for the April 2017 Trip (p. 128) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note (At least 24 White House and federal staffers stayed at Mar-a-Lago during the Xi visit. They included then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson; then-chief of staff Reince Priebus; then-Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; then-National Economic Council adviser Gary Cohn; and other advisers, past and present, such as Bannon, Hope Hicks, Stephen Miller and Sean Spicer.) A Manifest of Where Federal Employees Stayed During the April 2017 Mar-a-Lago Trip (p. 126) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note The State Department also broke with protocol regarding taxpayer-funded travel and applied for a Citibank travel card just for Mar-a-Lago visits. Meanwhile, other problems emerged: Mar-a-Lago canât process charges over $10,000, which led to problems when the club split bills and charged the government card for multiple transactions, emails show. Mar-a-Lago Can Only Charge Up to $10,000 On its Systems, Says State Department (p. 76) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note Mar-a-Lago refused government requests to waive the costs of its âfunction roomâ for press and other official meetings in April 2017, leading to a near-violation of a $3,500 government spending cap. Last year, Trump signed a law that lifted that cap, known as the âmicro-purchase threshold,â from $3,500 to $10,000. The law does not appear to have been aimed at facilitating spending at Mar-a-Lago, but it allows the club to avoid additional government contracting rules when charging sums below $10,000.In one instance, after the government was charged more than $3,500 for conference space at Mar-a-Lago, it asked the Trump Organization for a 10% discount so that it wouldnât violate the micro-purchase threshold. Mar-a-Lago relented, but only after months of haggling. The State Department Asks Mar-a-Lago for a 10% Discount on a Meeting Room, to Comply with Federal Rules (p. 45) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note In the emails, the director of presidential travel support, Michael Dobbs, frequently described the creation of a charge card unique to Mar-a-Lago as a âheadache.â State Department Contracting Officer Says Mar-a-Lago is a 'Headache' (p. 430) View the entire document with Document Cloud View note As Steve Schooner, a professor of government contracting law at George Washington University, put it, âThe fact that we have a State Department contracting officer saying this is a headache is a reminder that, but for the relationship with President Trump, this would not be a contract the government would be having. Thatâs a problem.â Many of the expenses incurred by White House staff are arranged and paid for by the White Houseâs Office of Administration. These expenses are not required to be made public. The same goes for Secret Service spending to protect the president on such visits. (The Government Accountability Office released a report last month evaluating spending at Mar-a-Lago in February and March 2017 and found that a total of $60,000 was spent at the hotel during four trips; the figure ran to $13.6 million when costs for plane travel, secret service, security and other logistics were included.) The State Department payments, and its work on behalf of the White House and other traveling staff, are considered public records. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. html.textContent: In April 2017, Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Mar-a-Lago, President Donald Trumpâs Palm Beach, Florida, estate and club, for a two-day summit. While Xi and his delegation stayed at a nearby hotel, Trump and his advisers stayed at the peach-colored, waterfront resort.

html.textContent: That evening, Trump and a dozen of his closest advisers hosted Xi and the Chinese delegation in an ornate dining room where they ate Dover sole and New York strip steak. Those sorts of lavish, formal gatherings are expected for a major bilateral summit.

html.textContent: But then there are less formal events. At some point later that evening, a group repaired to Mar-a-Lagoâs Library Bar, a wood-paneled study with a portrait of Trump in tennis whites (titled âThe Visionaryâ) hanging nearby. The group asked the bartender to leave the room so it âcould speak confidentially,â according to an email written by Mar-a-Lagoâs catering director, Brooke Watson.

html.textContent: Six days later, on April 13, Mar-a-Lago created a bill for those drinks, tallying $838 worth of alcohol plus a 20% service charge. It covered 54 drinks (making for an average price of $18.62 each) of premium liquor: Chopin vodka, Patron and Don Julio Blanco tequilas and Woodford Reserve bourbon. Watsonâs email did not specify how many people consumed the alcohol or who the participants were. (It stated that she was told the participants included then-strategist Steve Bannon and then-deputy chief of staff Joe Hagin. Bannon, who has said he stopped drinking years ago, said he didnât drink at Mar-a-Lago and didnât recall the episode. Hagin did not respond to requests for comment.)

html.textContent: The premium liquor costs are only the beginning of government spending at Mar-a-Lago that emerges in hundreds of pages of receipts and email correspondence between Trump Organization employees and staffers for the State Department, which oversees presidential diplomatic travel and works with the Secret Service and White House. The emails show that the presidentâs company refused to agree to what was essentially a bulk-purchase agreement with the federal government, and that it charged the maximum allowable federal rate for hotel rooms. The Trump Organization could be obstinate when it came to rates for, say, function rooms at Mar-a-Lago, a problem that was eased when the president signed a law lifting the maximum âmicro-purchaseâ the government can make.

The emails have been released as part of an ongoing lawsuit between the nonprofit Property of the People, a Washington-based transparency group, and the federal government. Property of the People provided the emails and receipts to ProPublica and we, in turn, have added them to our tracker of government spending at Trump-owned properties for our interactive graphic Paying the President. (The State Department is expected to release an additional 1,800 pages of records as part of the lawsuit, which was filed under the Freedom of Information Act.)

The emails show that âMar-a-Lago wanted to have the government money without the government rules,â said Charles Tiefer, a law professor at the University of Baltimore who served on the congressionally chartered Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan.

html.textContent: A few months after Trumpâs inauguration, the State Department proposed a contract that would pay $200,000 for all room costs for federal employees who stay at Mar-a-Lago over the first term of his presidency. But Mar-a-Lago rejected the governmentâs proposal. Instead, Trumpâs resort bills the government the maximum permitted by federal rules: 300% of the governmentâs per diem rate, which works out to $546 per night.

html.textContent: Mar-a-Lago rejected the proposed flat-fee arrangement, according to the emails, because of concerns the clubâs lawyers had about the Federal Acquisition Regulation, or FAR, which governs federal purchases and is overseen by contracting officers. FAR seeks to promote competition and maintain âthe publicâs trust.â
html.nouns: Lago proposedfee arrangement, emails, clubâs lawyers Federal Acquisition Regulation, purchases officers. seeks competition âthe publicâs trust.â

html.textContent: The emails suggest the Trump Organization was worried that the lack of competitive bidding could run afoul of federal rules, among other concerns. A State Department staffer wrote in May 2017 that Mar-a-Lagoâs attorneys brought up federal âsmall business set-asideâ requirements, which set strict rules for sole-source government bids for small businesses. The State Department staffer wrote that Mar-a-Lagoâs âconcerns are based on their general lack of knowledge on the applicability of the FAR regulations.â

Since Mar-a-Lago wouldnât agree to a bulk contract, the State Department had to go to Plan B. When it came to the meeting with Chinaâs president, for example, the agency had to go into some contortions to make Mar-a-Lagoâs $546 nightly room rate square with its rules on competitive bidding, given that there are other less expensive hotels nearby. At least 16 staffers stayed at the Hampton Inn in West Palm Beach; at least eight stayed at the nearby Hilton Garden Inn; and four others stayed at the Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa, where the press pool also stayed, according to a hotel manifest obtained through the FOIA lawsuit. The government-negotiated rates at those establishments ranged from $195 to $305 per night.

Mar-a-Lago refused government requests to waive the costs of its âfunction roomâ for press and other official meetings in April 2017, leading to a near-violation of a $3,500 government spending cap. Last year, Trump signed a law that lifted that cap, known as the âmicro-purchase threshold,â from $3,500 to $10,000. The law does not appear to have been aimed at facilitating spending at Mar-a-Lago, but it allows the club to avoid additional government contracting rules when charging sums below $10,000.In one instance, after the government was charged more than $3,500 for conference space at Mar-a-Lago, it asked the Trump Organization for a 10% discount so that it wouldnât violate the micro-purchase threshold. Mar-a-Lago relented, but only after months of haggling.

html.textContent: Between 2015 and June of 2018, at least $16.1 million has poured into Trump Organization-managed and branded hotels, golf courses and restaurants from his campaign, Republican organizations and government agencies. Because Trumpâs business empire is overseen by a trust of which he is the sole beneficiary, he profits from these hotel stays, banquet hall rentals and meals.

The State Department and the White House have had exemptions included in their appropriations legislation to allow for alcohol purchases.

html.textContent: Six government contracting experts said Mar-a-Lago may be violating rules requiring competitive bids. They argue that Mar-a-Lagoâs practice of invoicing meeting spaces, hotel stays and meals separately is a way to get around federal spending rules.

html.textContent: âMar-a-Lago didnât want to compete, they wanted to sneak around the requirements, and charge much higher prices than the competition,â said Tiefer, who served as deputy general counsel with the House of Representatives for 11 years. âItâs not the first time in history that vendors have tried to get around the rules by charging individual components. This is familiar to every contracting officer. And itâs wrong. Itâs not just a technicality. Itâs not a game. The only safeguard the public has against the Trumps swallowing up all the government business is at least minimal competition.â
html.nouns: âMar-a-Lago didnât requirements, prices competition,â Tiefer, deputy counsel House of Representatives years. âItâs time history rules components.  familiar officer.  itâsItâs technicality. Itâs game. has Trumps government business competition.â

html.textContent: Several experts contend the State Department is exploiting loopholes in government spending rules to facilitate official gatherings at Mar-a-Lago. âItâs one of the biggest fears coming true, that they are bending over backwards to help the Trump Organization,â said Scott Amey, general counsel of the Project On Government Oversight. âIâm frustrated the State Department would exploit the system to bill Uncle Sam and the taxpayers. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. Itâs a worst-case scenario when it comes to conflicts of interest, with the president and his children putting themselves and profits ahead of the public.â

html.textContent: âTrump, Inc.â is exploring whether the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still enforcing consumer financial laws and holding companies accountable. We want to hear from people who work at the agency or left recently (particularly those familiar with enforcement actions, supervisory exams and areas such as payday lending and debt collection). Weâre also hoping to hear from consumers and companies who have interacted with the bureau in recent years. Find out more and tell us what you know.

How Taxpayers Covered a $1,000 Liquor Bill for Trump Staffers (and More) at Trumpâs Club

In April 2017, Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Mar-a-Lago, President Donald Trumpâs Palm Beach, Florida, estate and club, for a two-day summit. While Xi and his delegation stayed at a nearby hotel, Trump and his advisers stayed at the peach-colored, waterfront resort.

That evening, Trump and a dozen of his closest advisers hosted Xi and the Chinese delegation in an ornate dining room where they ate Dover sole and New York strip steak. Those sorts of lavish, formal gatherings are expected for a major bilateral summit.

But then there are less formal events. At some point later that evening, a group repaired to Mar-a-Lagoâs Library Bar, a wood-paneled study with a portrait of Trump in tennis whites (titled âThe Visionaryâ) hanging nearby. The group asked the bartender to leave the room so it âcould speak confidentially,â according to an email written by Mar-a-Lagoâs catering director, Brooke Watson.

The Secret Service guarded the door, according to the email. The bartender wasnât allowed to return. And members of the group began pouring themselves drinks. No one paid.

Six days later, on April 13, Mar-a-Lago created a bill for those drinks, tallying $838 worth of alcohol plus a 20% service charge. It covered 54 drinks (making for an average price of $18.62 each) of premium liquor: Chopin vodka, Patron and Don Julio Blanco tequilas and Woodford Reserve bourbon. Watsonâs email did not specify how many people consumed the alcohol or who the participants were. (It stated that she was told the participants included then-strategist Steve Bannon and then-deputy chief of staff Joe Hagin. Bannon, who has said he stopped drinking years ago, said he didnât drink at Mar-a-Lago and didnât recall the episode. Hagin did not respond to requests for comment.)

The bill was sent to the State Department, which objected to covering it. It was then forwarded to the White House, which paid the tab.

The unusual cocktail hour underscores a unique push and pull in the current administration: Donald Trumpâs White House pays a bill and Donald Trumpâs club reaps the revenue. (Itâs unclear if the White House asked any of those drinking to reimburse the government; the White House declined to comment.)

The premium liquor costs are only the beginning of government spending at Mar-a-Lago that emerges in hundreds of pages of receipts and email correspondence between Trump Organization employees and staffers for the State Department, which oversees presidential diplomatic travel and works with the Secret Service and White House. The emails show that the presidentâs company refused to agree to what was essentially a bulk-purchase agreement with the federal government, and that it charged the maximum allowable federal rate for hotel rooms. The Trump Organization could be obstinate when it came to rates for, say, function rooms at Mar-a-Lago, a problem that was eased when the president signed a law lifting the maximum âmicro-purchaseâ the government can make.

The emails have been released as part of an ongoing lawsuit between the nonprofit Property of the People, a Washington-based transparency group, and the federal government. Property of the People provided the emails and receipts to ProPublica and we, in turn, have added them to our tracker of government spending at Trump-owned properties for our interactive graphic Paying the President. (The State Department is expected to release an additional 1,800 pages of records as part of the lawsuit, which was filed under the Freedom of Information Act.)

In response to questions from ProPublica, the State Department asked for and received the documents described in this article. State Department officials promised a detailed response, but then declined comment.

The documents reveal the intersection between Trumpâs conflicting interests. The emails show that âMar-a-Lago wanted to have the government money without the government rules,â said Charles Tiefer, a law professor at the University of Baltimore who served on the congressionally chartered Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan.

A few months after Trumpâs inauguration, the State Department proposed a contract that would pay $200,000 for all room costs for federal employees who stay at Mar-a-Lago over the first term of his presidency. But Mar-a-Lago rejected the governmentâs proposal. Instead, Trumpâs resort bills the government the maximum permitted by federal rules: 300% of the governmentâs per diem rate, which works out to $546 per night.

Mar-a-Lago rejected the proposed flat-fee arrangement, according to the emails, because of concerns the clubâs lawyers had about the Federal Acquisition Regulation, or FAR, which governs federal purchases and is overseen by contracting officers. FAR seeks to promote competition and maintain âthe publicâs trust.â

The emails suggest the Trump Organization was worried that the lack of competitive bidding could run afoul of federal rules, among other concerns. A State Department staffer wrote in May 2017 that Mar-a-Lagoâs attorneys brought up federal âsmall business set-asideâ requirements, which set strict rules for sole-source government bids for small businesses. The State Department staffer wrote that Mar-a-Lagoâs âconcerns are based on their general lack of knowledge on the applicability of the FAR regulations.â

Mar-a-Lago and the Trump Organization did not respond to ProPublicaâs requests for comment.

Since Mar-a-Lago wouldnât agree to a bulk contract, the State Department had to go to Plan B. When it came to the meeting with Chinaâs president, for example, the agency had to go into some contortions to make Mar-a-Lagoâs $546 nightly room rate square with its rules on competitive bidding, given that there are other less expensive hotels nearby. At least 16 staffers stayed at the Hampton Inn in West Palm Beach; at least eight stayed at the nearby Hilton Garden Inn; and four others stayed at the Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa, where the press pool also stayed, according to a hotel manifest obtained through the FOIA lawsuit. The government-negotiated rates at those establishments ranged from $195 to $305 per night.

(At least 24 White House and federal staffers stayed at Mar-a-Lago during the Xi visit. They included then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson; then-chief of staff Reince Priebus; then-Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; then-National Economic Council adviser Gary Cohn; and other advisers, past and present, such as Bannon, Hope Hicks, Stephen Miller and Sean Spicer.)

The State Department also broke with protocol regarding taxpayer-funded travel and applied for a Citibank travel card just for Mar-a-Lago visits.

Meanwhile, other problems emerged:

  • Mar-a-Lago canât process charges over $10,000, which led to problems when the club split bills and charged the government card for multiple transactions, emails show.

  • Mar-a-Lago refused government requests to waive the costs of its âfunction roomâ for press and other official meetings in April 2017, leading to a near-violation of a $3,500 government spending cap. Last year, Trump signed a law that lifted that cap, known as the âmicro-purchase threshold,â from $3,500 to $10,000. The law does not appear to have been aimed at facilitating spending at Mar-a-Lago, but it allows the club to avoid additional government contracting rules when charging sums below $10,000.
  • In one instance, after the government was charged more than $3,500 for conference space at Mar-a-Lago, it asked the Trump Organization for a 10% discount so that it wouldnât violate the micro-purchase threshold. Mar-a-Lago relented, but only after months of haggling.

In the emails, the director of presidential travel support, Michael Dobbs, frequently described the creation of a charge card unique to Mar-a-Lago as a âheadache.â

As Steve Schooner, a professor of government contracting law at George Washington University, put it, âThe fact that we have a State Department contracting officer saying this is a headache is a reminder that, but for the relationship with President Trump, this would not be a contract the government would be having. Thatâs a problem.â

Many of the expenses incurred by White House staff are arranged and paid for by the White Houseâs Office of Administration. These expenses are not required to be made public. The same goes for Secret Service spending to protect the president on such visits. (The Government Accountability Office released a report last month evaluating spending at Mar-a-Lago in February and March 2017 and found that a total of $60,000 was spent at the hotel during four trips; the figure ran to $13.6 million when costs for plane travel, secret service, security and other logistics were included.)

The State Department payments, and its work on behalf of the White House and other traveling staff, are considered public records.

Between 2015 and June of 2018, at least $16.1 million has poured into Trump Organization-managed and branded hotels, golf courses and restaurants from his campaign, Republican organizations and government agencies. Because Trumpâs business empire is overseen by a trust of which he is the sole beneficiary, he profits from these hotel stays, banquet hall rentals and meals.

Federal spending rules donât specifically address agency-level spending on alcohol that is directly invoiced to the government, as occurred with the $1,000 bar tab at Mar-a-Lago. The State Department and the White House have had exemptions included in their appropriations legislation to allow for alcohol purchases.

Individual government employees are not permitted to use charge cards for âimproperâ purposes, such as alcohol, and federal per diem rules allow for charges for breakfast, lunch, dinner and related tips and taxes but specifically exclude alcoholic drinks.

Six government contracting experts said Mar-a-Lago may be violating rules requiring competitive bids. They argue that Mar-a-Lagoâs practice of invoicing meeting spaces, hotel stays and meals separately is a way to get around federal spending rules.

âMar-a-Lago didnât want to compete, they wanted to sneak around the requirements, and charge much higher prices than the competition,â said Tiefer, who served as deputy general counsel with the House of Representatives for 11 years. âItâs not the first time in history that vendors have tried to get around the rules by charging individual components. This is familiar to every contracting officer. And itâs wrong. Itâs not just a technicality. Itâs not a game. The only safeguard the public has against the Trumps swallowing up all the government business is at least minimal competition.â

Several experts contend the State Department is exploiting loopholes in government spending rules to facilitate official gatherings at Mar-a-Lago. âItâs one of the biggest fears coming true, that they are bending over backwards to help the Trump Organization,â said Scott Amey, general counsel of the Project On Government Oversight. âIâm frustrated the State Department would exploit the system to bill Uncle Sam and the taxpayers. To have the government bicker to get a 10% discount shows the Trump Organization isnât putting the American public first. Itâs a worst-case scenario when it comes to conflicts of interest, with the president and his children putting themselves and profits ahead of the public.â

âTrump, Inc.â is exploring whether the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still enforcing consumer financial laws and holding companies accountable. We want to hear from people who work at the agency or left recently (particularly those familiar with enforcement actions, supervisory exams and areas such as payday lending and debt collection). Weâre also hoping to hear from consumers and companies who have interacted with the bureau in recent years. Find out more and tell us what you know.
